facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 193 of 1952 was filed by special leave from the High Court judgment dated 21st December 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 193 of 1952. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment dated the 21st -December, 1951,

facts.text: The appeal arises out of the Judgment and Decree dated 18th January 1943 of the Court of District Judge, Kottayam.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment dated the 21st -December, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature of Travancore-Cochin arising out of the Judgment and Decree dated the 18th January, -1943,

facts.text: Review application was made on 22nd August 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It will be recalled that the present review application was made on the 22nd August, 1946, and a notice to show cause was issued on the 4th December, 1947.

facts.text: Notice to show cause was issued on 4th December 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the present review application was made on the 22nd August, 1946, and a notice to show cause was issued on the 4th December, 1947. The preliminary question as to the maintainability

facts.text: Preliminary question as to maintainability of review application decided on 29th June 1949.

anchor.surface_text: 1947. The preliminary question as to the maintainability of the review application was decided on the 29th June, 1949. During all this period Regulation IV of 1099

facts.text: Covenant of merger between Rulers of Travancore and Cochin dated 29th May 1949, effective from 1st July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime on the 29th May, 1949, came the Covenant of merger between the Rulers of Travancore and Cochin with the concurrence and guarantee of the then Governor-General of India

facts.text: Ordinance No. I of 1124 promulgated by Rajpramukh on 1st July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred on him by article XI of the Covenant the Rajpramukh on the. 1st July, 1949, promulgated Ordinance No. I of 1124.

facts.text: Ordinance No. II of 1124 issued on 7th July 1949 repealed Travancore High Court Act Regulation IV of 1099.

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th July, 1949, however, came Ordinance No. II of 1124. Clause 4 of this Ordinance repealed the Travancore High Court Act  Regulation IV of 1099 .

facts.text: Karingasserai meeting in August 1935 where first plaintiff elected as Malankara Metropolitan and ex-officio trustee, and plaintiffs 2 and 3 as co-trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The first objection relates to the validity of the election of the first plaintiff as the Malankara Metropolitan and as such the ex-officio trustee and the elections of plaintiffs 2 and 3 as his co-trustees at the Karingasserai meeting.

facts.text: Defendants rely on meeting at M. D. Seminary in December 1934.

anchor.surface_text: This meeting is pleaded in paragraphs 13 and 14 of the plaint,. In paragraph 18 of the plaint the plaintiffs refer to the meeting said to have been held at the M. D. Seminary in December, 1934,

facts.text: District Judge held that Karingasserai meeting was not convened by competent persons.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge in paragraph 164 of the judgment held, for reasons stated by him, that that meeting had not been convened by competent persons

facts.text: District Judge held that notice of Karingasserai meeting was not given to all churches.

anchor.surface_text: and in paragraph 165 he found that notice of the said meeting had not been given to all the churches.

facts.text: Plaintiffs' advocate conceded no evidence to prove notices issued to all churches prior to 1086.

anchor.surface_text: It having been conceded by the plaintiffs advocate at the time of the final argument before the District Judge that there is no evidence on the plaintiffs side to prove that all the churches

facts.text: Defendants adopted new constitution Ex. AM.

anchor.surface_text: in the view of the plaintiffs party the defendants and their partisans by adopting the new constitution Ex. AM had become aliens to the Church

facts.text: Adoption of new constitution Ex. AM took place in 1934, about 8 months before Karingasserai meeting.

anchor.surface_text: that the adoption of the new constitution was clear evidence of the defendants repudiation of the Patriarchs church, and of the fact that the adoption took place in 1934 about 8 months earlier

facts.text: High Court majority held Karingasserai meeting valid, reversing District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the judgment of the High Court it appears that the majority of the Judges dealt with the question of the validity of the meeting in a superficial and summary manner.

facts.text: District Judge found acts imputed to defendants did not amount to heresy or secession.

anchor.surface_text: In Paragraph 132 of his judgment the learned District judge found that the acts and claims imputed to the defendants did not amount to heresy and did not make the defendants

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in paragraph 133 the District Judge held that the plaintiffs and their adherents by taking up the position which they adopted in 1085

facts.text: Defendants' advocate stated to have conceded plaintiffs had not left the church.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court judgments defective on face due to not addressing competency of conveners and notice for Karingasserai meeting.

anchor.surface_text: The majority judgments, therefore, are defective on the face of them in that they did not effectively deal with and determine an important issue in the case

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court judgment, admits review.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review.

facts.text: Review sought on grounds of error apparent on face of record regarding validity of Karingasserai meeting.

holdings.text: The preliminary objection that the review application has become infructuous due to changes in judicial administration and repeal of Regulation IV of 1099 is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this contention is not well founded. The application for review was properly made to the Travancore High Court and the Travancore High Court had to decide whether to admit or to reject the application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review properly instituted pre-changes and pending; continued under s.8 Ordinance II of 1124, s.8 Act 1125; revived appeal disposed under s.25 without Maharaja confirmation needed; arts 214,225 preserve jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Scope of review under Travancore CPC (equiv. O47 R1 CPC) limited to: (i) new evidence, (ii) error apparent on face of record, (iii) any other sufficient reason analogous to above.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions in the Travancore Code of Civil Procedure which is similar in terms to Order XLVII, rule I of our Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, the Court of review has only a limited jurisdiction circumscribed by the definitive limits fixed by the lan

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual limits of rule; analogous reason per Judicial Committee precedents (Chhajju Ram, Bisheshwar; adopted FC Hari Shankar).

holdings.text: High Court majority judgments defective on face with error apparent: failed to address competency of Karingasserai meeting conveners and notice to all non-Ex.AM churches.

anchor.surface_text: The majority judgments, therefore, are defective on the face of them in that they did not effectively deal with and determine an important issue in the case on which depends the title of the plaintiffs and the maintainability of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Key issue 1(b),6(a) for plaintiffs' trustee title ignored; superficial reversal of DJ findings on conceded no pre-1086 notices, convener competency; plaintiff must prove own title.

holdings.text: Misconception of defendants' counsel concession (plaintiffs not left church) constitutes sufficient reason analogous to error apparent on face; affidavit/letters permissible to prove.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the defendants appellants contends that this was a misapprehension and he relies on the affidavit of Sri E. J. Philipose, advocate, with which were produced two letters written to him by the senior advocate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapprehension proven by affidavit/letters part of broad record; failed symmetric analysis of plaintiffs' acts (iss 19-20) vs defendants' (14-15) for heresy/secession; no ipso facto without ecclesiastical verdict.

holdings.text: Affidavit evidence of counsel's letters establishing misconception of concession is part of record for review under O47 R1 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it is permissible to rely on the affidavit as an additional ground for review of the judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconception analogous to facial error; permissible per PC/this Court (not restricted as in Sha Mulchand); proper via review.

holdings.text: High Court erred by deciding excluded matters under issue 11(a) (general Patriarch powers), constituting error apparent on face.

anchor.surface_text: To decide against a party on matters which do not come within the issues on which the parties went to trial clearly amounts to an error apparent on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement excluded general powers; went into unpleaded installation obedience, faith decisions, Catholicos approval; beyond issues.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; review admitted; entire appeal reheard unless parties accept HC findings.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid grounds of error apparent/sufficient reason established on multiple heads.

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri J.  as he then was  sitting singly in the Madras High Court definitely took the view in Rekhanti Chinna Govinda Chettiyar v. S. Varadappa Chettiar 2  that a misconception by the Court of a concession made by the Advocate or of the attitude taken up by the party appears to be a ground analogous to the grounds set forth in the first part of the review section and affords a good and cogent ground for review. A.I.R. 194o mad, 17.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review. As the different points involved in this appeal are intimately interconnected we direct the entire appeal to be reheard on all points unless both parties accept any of the findings of the High Court.
